content: Swine flu, aka "Gerald Ford's Folly." That well-intentioned effort single-handedly and significantly set back the CDC's annual flu-prevention program for years. The one tangible benefit to come out of it was the wide recognition of Guillian-Barre as an uncommon but serious potential side effect of immunizations. Swine flu IS real, has always been real, and always been lurking in the background. SARS and Avian Flu have not gone away, either. Sooner or later on one of those, or another variation that has not yet hit critical mass for publicity, WILL become pandemic. As far as swine flu is concerned, there is a preventive vaccine that needs to be tweaked in formulation. It will work for many people - but NOT 100% of the people 100% of the time, nor will it be without some side effects that for some people will be quite serious. Just sayin'.

content: This flu is going to be unlike any flu you have seen before. This flu attacks normal healthy adults not just predominantly the immuno-depressed types... elderly and the very young. I posted the below in "In The News" a few minutes ago. quote: Sorry, I will not have time to do a follow up on this so ya all are going to just have to do your own research. WITHIN DAYS of the CDC (Atlanta) receiving a virus sample from the Mexican Government, the CDC defined this virus as totally new... and totally unique. We are about ten days downrange from that date if memory serves. The states of Texas and California didn't know they were dealing with a new virus either as there have only been 2-3 cases reported (as of now) since the CDC made its declaration. San Diego County and Imperial County (on the mexican border) in California... and one single city in Texas are the only known US cases. Again... this information has only arisen AFTER the Mexican Government sent CDC the sample for identification. Prior to that Mexico was thinking that they just had an outbreak of an existing flu type. But now that government is taking rather strict actions to limit its further spread... actions that the CDC thinks may be too late. As for the mortality rate... no one has died in the USA. Perhaps because we have better medical aid for the most part. In Mexico a little under 1100 cases have been identified so far since testing for the exact CDC confirmed virus began. Of taht at LEAST 62 deaths have already resulted. That is roughly 6% mortality rate... That is very high by US standards. Again it is not known exactly how many deats or infections there actually are in Mexico at this point. too much is never reported there. BTW: say 100 million Americans get exposed to this new virus... do you think a 5% or 6% mortality rate could be realistic? I am not certain myself. My fear is that Mexico is NOT ground zero for this virus strain. I am kind of worried that it originated in points south of Mexico where reporting is almost non-existant. And for a few more months I have loved ones down there... working it the area where viruses incubate and are easily transmitted. There is no cure or prevention for this swine flu bug. All one can do is ride it out. Not the best answer for a warm and fuzzy feeling.

content: My first memory of the Swine Flu was in 76 or 77 when we were out beyond Area J on Bragg on an FTX. The flu vaccinations that year caused roughly a 33% illness rate that kept us medics hoping in diagnosing and even medically evac'ing to Womack Army Medical Center 24 hours a day for 3 days straight. That was a nightmare time and we got very little sleep. I still have a few photos of those three days. But this one is going to be different. if this is an epidemic or Pandemic (as some experts think it may make it to) then it is going to be 3-4 months before the first vaccine can be made commercially for broad distribution. That could be worrisome

content: quote: The New York City health department dispatched a team of investigators to a private school in Queens on Friday after dozens of students complained of symptoms that officials believed were consistent with a strain of swine flu that has swept Mexico City. The agency said about 75 students at St. Francis Preparatory School had complained Thursday of nausea, fever, dizziness and aches and pains. Several of the students were said to have recently traveled to Mexico, where as many as 61 people have died and possibly hundreds more have been infected in an outbreak of swine flu in recent weeks.

content: A few things to know about swine flu, treatment Q What is swine flu? A Swine flu is a respiratory illness in pigs caused by a virus. The swine flu virus routinely causes outbreaks in pigs but doesn't usually kill many of them. Q Can people get swine flu? A Swine flu viruses don't usually infect humans. There have been occasional cases, usually among people who've had direct contact with infected pigs, such as farmworkers. Q Can it spread among humans? A There have been cases of the virus spreading from human to human, probably in the same way as seasonal flu, through coughing and sneezing by infected people. Q What are the symptoms of swine flu? A The symptoms are similar to those of regular flu -- fever, cough, fatigue, lack of appetite. Q Are there drugs to treat swine flu in humans? A Four different drugs are approved in the U.S. to treat the flu, but the new virus has shown resistance to the two oldest. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends the use of the flu drugs Tamiflu and Relenza. Q Does a regular flu shot protect against swine flu? A The seasonal flu vaccine used in the U.S. this year is not likely to protect against the latest swine flu virus. Source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. For more information: >>>www.cdc.gov/flu/swine/key_facts.htm

content: quote: Worries that the new swine flu strain that has killed as many as 68 people and sickened more than 1,000 across Mexico has “pandemic potential” increased with the announcement that the virus had spread to Kansas, and likely to New York City. On Saturday, two new cases of swine flu were confirmed in Kansas. And New York City Health Commissioner Dr. Thomas Frieden announced that tests showed that eight New York schoolchildren had a type A influenza virus that was likely the swine flu. Good god....We were due for a pandemic, and this might be it. With a 6% fatality rate so far in Mexico, just several hundred thousands cases in the US will be catastrophic... California, Texas, Kansas, New York.....its out.

content: This flu is going to be unlike any flu you have seen before. This flu attacks normal healthy adults not just predominantly the immuno-depressed types... elderly and the very young. I posted the below in "In The News" a few minutes ago. quote: Sorry, I will not have time to do a follow up on this so ya all are going to just have to do your own research. WITHIN DAYS of the CDC (Atlanta) receiving a virus sample from the Mexican Government, the CDC defined this virus as totally new... and totally unique. We are about ten days downrange from that date if memory serves. The states of Texas and California didn't know they were dealing with a new virus either as there have only been 2-3 cases reported (as of now) since the CDC made its declaration. San Diego County and Imperial County (on the mexican border) in California... and one single city in Texas are the only known US cases. Again... this information has only arisen AFTER the Mexican Government sent CDC the sample for identification. Prior to that Mexico was thinking that they just had an outbreak of an existing flu type. But now that government is taking rather strict actions to limit its further spread... actions that the CDC thinks may be too late. As for the mortality rate... no one has died in the USA. Perhaps because we have better medical aid for the most part. In Mexico a little under 1100 cases have been identified so far since testing for the exact CDC confirmed virus began. Of taht at LEAST 62 deaths have already resulted. That is roughly 6% mortality rate... That is very high by US standards. Again it is not known exactly how many deats or infections there actually are in Mexico at this point. too much is never reported there. BTW: say 100 million Americans get exposed to this new virus... do you think a 5% or 6% mortality rate could be realistic? I am not certain myself. My fear is that Mexico is NOT ground zero for this virus strain. I am kind of worried that it originated in points south of Mexico where reporting is almost non-existant. And for a few more months I have loved ones down there... working it the area where viruses incubate and are easily transmitted. There is no cure or prevention for this swine flu bug. All one can do is ride it out. Not the best answer for a warm and fuzzy feeling.

content: My first memory of the Swine Flu was in 76 or 77 when we were out beyond Area J on Bragg on an FTX. The flu vaccinations that year caused roughly a 33% illness rate that kept us medics hoping in diagnosing and even medically evac'ing to Womack Army Medical Center 24 hours a day for 3 days straight. That was a nightmare time and we got very little sleep. I still have a few photos of those three days. But this one is going to be different. if this is an epidemic or Pandemic (as some experts think it may make it to) then it is going to be 3-4 months before the first vaccine can be made commercially for broad distribution. That could be worrisome

The agency said about 75 students at St. Francis Preparatory School had complained Thursday of nausea, fever, dizziness and aches and pains. Several of the students were said to have recently traveled to Mexico, where as many as 61 people have died and possibly hundreds more have been infected in an outbreak of swine flu in recent weeks.

content: A few things to know about swine flu, treatment Q What is swine flu? A Swine flu is a respiratory illness in pigs caused by a virus. The swine flu virus routinely causes outbreaks in pigs but doesn't usually kill many of them. Q Can people get swine flu? A Swine flu viruses don't usually infect humans. There have been occasional cases, usually among people who've had direct contact with infected pigs, such as farmworkers. Q Can it spread among humans? A There have been cases of the virus spreading from human to human, probably in the same way as seasonal flu, through coughing and sneezing by infected people. Q What are the symptoms of swine flu? A The symptoms are similar to those of regular flu -- fever, cough, fatigue, lack of appetite. Q Are there drugs to treat swine flu in humans? A Four different drugs are approved in the U.S. to treat the flu, but the new virus has shown resistance to the two oldest. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends the use of the flu drugs Tamiflu and Relenza. Q Does a regular flu shot protect against swine flu? A The seasonal flu vaccine used in the U.S. this year is not likely to protect against the latest swine flu virus. Source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. For more information: >>>www.cdc.gov/flu/swine/key_facts.htm

content: Swine flu, aka "Gerald Ford's Folly." That well-intentioned effort single-handedly and significantly set back the CDC's annual flu-prevention program for years. The one tangible benefit to come out of it was the wide recognition of Guillian-Barre as an uncommon but serious potential side effect of immunizations. Swine flu IS real, has always been real, and always been lurking in the background. SARS and Avian Flu have not gone away, either. Sooner or later on one of those, or another variation that has not yet hit critical mass for publicity, WILL become pandemic. As far as swine flu is concerned, there is a preventive vaccine that needs to be tweaked in formulation. It will work for many people - but NOT 100% of the people 100% of the time, nor will it be without some side effects that for some people will be quite serious. Just sayin'.

content: My first memory of the Swine Flu was in 76 or 77 when we were out beyond Area J on Bragg on an FTX. The flu vaccinations that year caused roughly a 33% illness rate that kept us medics hoping in diagnosing and even medically evac'ing to Womack Army Medical Center 24 hours a day for 3 days straight. That was a nightmare time and we got very little sleep. I still have a few photos of those three days. But this one is going to be different. if this is an epidemic or Pandemic (as some experts think it may make it to) then it is going to be 3-4 months before the first vaccine can be made commercially for broad distribution. That could be worrisome

The agency said about 75 students at St. Francis Preparatory School had complained Thursday of nausea, fever, dizziness and aches and pains. content: A few things to know about swine flu, treatment Q What is swine flu? A Swine flu is a respiratory illness in pigs caused by a virus. The swine flu virus routinely causes outbreaks in pigs but doesn't usually kill many of them. Q Can people get swine flu? A Swine flu viruses don't usually infect humans. There have been occasional cases, usually among people who've had direct contact with infected pigs, such as farmworkers. Q Can it spread among humans? A There have been cases of the virus spreading from human to human, probably in the same way as seasonal flu, through coughing and sneezing by infected people. Q What are the symptoms of swine flu? A The symptoms are similar to those of regular flu -- fever, cough, fatigue, lack of appetite. Q Are there drugs to treat swine flu in humans? A Four different drugs are approved in the U.S. to treat the flu, but the new virus has shown resistance to the two oldest. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends the use of the flu drugs Tamiflu and Relenza. Q Does a regular flu shot protect against swine flu? A The seasonal flu vaccine used in the U.S. this year is not likely to protect against the latest swine flu virus. Source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. For more information: >>>www.cdc.gov/flu/swine/key_facts.htm

content: quote: Worries that the new swine flu strain that has killed as many as 68 people and sickened more than 1,000 across Mexico has “pandemic potential” increased with the announcement that the virus had spread to Kansas, and likely to New York City. On Saturday, two new cases of swine flu were confirmed in Kansas. And New York City Health Commissioner Dr. Thomas Frieden announced that tests showed that eight New York schoolchildren had a type A influenza virus that was likely the swine flu. Good god....We were due for a pandemic, and this might be it. With a 6% fatality rate so far in Mexico, just several hundred thousands cases in the US will be catastrophic... California, Texas, Kansas, New York.....its out.

content: Swine flu, aka "Gerald Ford's Folly." That well-intentioned effort single-handedly and significantly set back the CDC's annual flu-prevention program for years. The one tangible benefit to come out of it was the wide recognition of Guillian-Barre as an uncommon but serious potential side effect of immunizations. Swine flu IS real, has always been real, and always been lurking in the background. SARS and Avian Flu have not gone away, either. Sooner or later on one of those, or another variation that has not yet hit critical mass for publicity, WILL become pandemic. As far as swine flu is concerned, there is a preventive vaccine that needs to be tweaked in formulation. It will work for many people - but NOT 100% of the people 100% of the time, nor will it be without some side effects that for some people will be quite serious. Just sayin'.

content: This flu is going to be unlike any flu you have seen before. This flu attacks normal healthy adults not just predominantly the immuno-depressed types... elderly and the very young. I posted the below in "In The News" a few minutes ago. quote: Sorry, I will not have time to do a follow up on this so ya all are going to just have to do your own research. WITHIN DAYS of the CDC (Atlanta) receiving a virus sample from the Mexican Government, the CDC defined this virus as totally new... and totally unique. We are about ten days downrange from that date if memory serves. The states of Texas and California didn't know they were dealing with a new virus either as there have only been 2-3 cases reported (as of now) since the CDC made its declaration. San Diego County and Imperial County (on the mexican border) in California... and one single city in Texas are the only known US cases. Again... this information has only arisen AFTER the Mexican Government sent CDC the sample for identification. Prior to that Mexico was thinking that they just had an outbreak of an existing flu type. But now that government is taking rather strict actions to limit its further spread... actions that the CDC thinks may be too late. As for the mortality rate... no one has died in the USA. Perhaps because we have better medical aid for the most part. In Mexico a little under 1100 cases have been identified so far since testing for the exact CDC confirmed virus began. Of taht at LEAST 62 deaths have already resulted. That is roughly 6% mortality rate... That is very high by US standards. Again it is not known exactly how many deats or infections there actually are in Mexico at this point. too much is never reported there. BTW: say 100 million Americans get exposed to this new virus... do you think a 5% or 6% mortality rate could be realistic? I am not certain myself. My fear is that Mexico is NOT ground zero for this virus strain. I am kind of worried that it originated in points south of Mexico where reporting is almost non-existant. And for a few more months I have loved ones down there... working it the area where viruses incubate and are easily transmitted. There is no cure or prevention for this swine flu bug. All one can do is ride it out. Not the best answer for a warm and fuzzy feeling.

The agency said about 75 students at St. Francis Preparatory School had complained Thursday of nausea, fever, dizziness and aches and pains. Several of the students were said to have recently traveled to Mexico, where as many as 61 people have died and possibly hundreds more have been infected in an outbreak of swine flu in recent weeks.
title: Swine Flu

content: A few things to know about swine flu, treatment Q What is swine flu? A Swine flu is a respiratory illness in pigs caused by a virus. The swine flu virus routinely causes outbreaks in pigs but doesn't usually kill many of them. Q Can people get swine flu? A Swine flu viruses don't usually infect humans. There have been occasional cases, usually among people who've had direct contact with infected pigs, such as farmworkers. Q Can it spread among humans? A There have been cases of the virus spreading from human to human, probably in the same way as seasonal flu, through coughing and sneezing by infected people. Q What are the symptoms of swine flu? A The symptoms are similar to those of regular flu -- fever, cough, fatigue, lack of appetite. Q Are there drugs to treat swine flu in humans? A Four different drugs are approved in the U.S. to treat the flu, but the new virus has shown resistance to the two oldest. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends the use of the flu drugs Tamiflu and Relenza. Q Does a regular flu shot protect against swine flu? A The seasonal flu vaccine used in the U.S. this year is not likely to protect against the latest swine flu virus. Source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. For more information: >>>www.cdc.gov/flu/swine/key_facts.htm

content: quote: Worries that the new swine flu strain that has killed as many as 68 people and sickened more than 1,000 across Mexico has “pandemic potential” increased with the announcement that the virus had spread to Kansas, and likely to New York City. On Saturday, two new cases of swine flu were confirmed in Kansas. And New York City Health Commissioner Dr. Thomas Frieden announced that tests showed that eight New York schoolchildren had a type A influenza virus that was likely the swine flu. Good god....We were due for a pandemic, and this might be it. With a 6% fatality rate so far in Mexico, just several hundred thousands cases in the US will be catastrophic... California, Texas, Kansas, New York.....its out.
